Letters to the editor
Campus Security
To the Editors:
I've read with interest and concern
News-Letter coverage of the measures
proposed for increased campus security.
It seems to me that much of this security
talk proceeds on the ground that women
are helpless, foolish creatures. I think this
premise is false, even insulting, but I'm
writing princcipally to call critical
attention to sodium vapor lighting. These
high intensity lights cannot guarantee
safety, are overly expensive, and
exceedingly hideous.
For an urban campus, Homewood has

a particular charm and a distinct Georgian
grace. While I hardly propose that we
revert to gas lamps in order to match the
tone of the buildings and grounds, I
would say a word in favor of the present
mercury vapor lights. They provide a
sensible, proportionate amount of light
when properly distributed. Why not
preserve a few quiet places on campus,
where one may walk and think with some
reasonable solitlude, where, on a warm
evening, we can get away and forget for a
moment the asphalt, neon flashes, and
chain link fences of the city. There are
few such escapes left. If we install sodium
vapor lights at Homewood we will have

perpetual, horrid daylight: an Orwelllan
nightmare. Everything will be flooded in
the pink glow of a railroad flare at a
disaster scene. There are parts of the city
where this blinding glare is sadly
necessary, but the Keyser quadrangle is
not the Mt. Sinai Hospital parking lot.
Sodium vapor lights would, in an
awsthetic sense, kill the campus to save it.
My objections are not to a well-lighted
campus nor, certainly, to a secure one. If
more mecury lights are necessary, then let
us install them. But we must avoid
over-reaction. Sodium vapor lights cannot
protect anyone from daytime assault (one
of the rape attempts occurred in the

afternoon); we need to avoid excessive
expense (the financial plight of the
University is well enough publicized); and
day or night, for women and for those
men who fear physical or sexual assault,
the best defense is common sense
precaution. The University has retained
the consulting engineers Egli and Gampf,
Inc. to deal with the security problem on
the Hopkins campus. I, for one, hope
that they will recognize the unacceptable
expense and irreparable aesthetic damage
that the proposed sodium vapor system,
Big Brother's answer to the 4th of July,
would bring to Homewood. Pat trugger

The markup guideline on merchandise,
allegedly violated by Giant Food Inc., is
based on the percentage of markup on
items from wholesale to retail prices.

1971. The markup percentage
cannot exceed the highest figure for
those three years.
For instance, if the highest
markup on meat for the three
year period was 12 percent,
then present price markups
cannot exceed that percentage
figure, according to
Commission guidelines.
The price freeze for
Giant Food Inc. will remain
in effect until the company
submits a plan for reduction
of prices that will make up
the alleged excessive profit. The
Price Commission has given Giant
until Dec. 19 to submit a plan. The
plan would entail reduction of
prices based on the percentage of
excessibe profits. Prices would remain
in a reduced state until the excess
markup profit had been eliminate by
the reduction.

Campus Security
To the Editors:
I've read with interest and concern
News-Letter coverage of the measures
proposed for increased campus security.
It seems to me that much of this security
talk proceeds on the ground that women
are helpless, foolish creatures. I think this
premise is false, even insulting, but I'm
writing princcipally to call critical
attention to sodium vapor lighting. These
high intensity lights cannot guarantee
safety, are overly expensive, and
exceedingly hideous.
For an urban campus, Homewood has

a particular charm and a distinct Georgian
grace. While I hardly propose that we
revert to gas lamps in order to match the
tone of the buildings and grounds, I
would say a word in favor of the present
mercury vapor lights. They provide a
sensible, proportionate amount of light
when properly distributed. Why not
preserve a few quiet places on campus,
where one may walk and think with some
reasonable solitlude, where, on a warm
evening, we can get away and forget for a
moment the asphalt, neon flashes, and
chain link fences of the city. There are
few such escapes left. If we install sodium
vapor lights at Homewood we will have

perpetual, horrid daylight: an Orwelllan
nightmare. Everything will be flooded in
the pink glow of a railroad flare at a
disaster scene. There are parts of the city
where this blinding glare is sadly
necessary, but the Keyser quadrangle is
not the Mt. Sinai Hospital parking lot.
Sodium vapor lights would, in an
awsthetic sense, kill the campus to save it.
My objections are not to a well-lighted
campus nor, certainly, to a secure one. If
more mecury lights are necessary, then let
us install them. But we must avoid
over-reaction. Sodium vapor lights cannot
protect anyone from daytime assault (one
of the rape attempts occurred in the

afternoon); we need to avoid excessive
expense (the financial plight of the
University is well enough publicized); and
day or night, for women and for those
men who fear physical or sexual assault,
the best defense is common sense
precaution. The University has retained
the consulting engineers Egli and Gampf,
Inc. to deal with the security problem on
the Hopkins campus. I, for one, hope
that they will recognize the unacceptable
expense and irreparable aesthetic damage
that the proposed sodium vapor system,
Big Brother's answer to the 4th of July,
would bring to Homewood. Pat trugger
